Contract Act, 1872 - S. 27 - Bar on post-contractual covenants or restrictions under - Scope - Held, bar on such covenants or restrictions is not confined only to contracts of employment, but is also applicable to all other contracts - Promotional/advertising/endorsement/event management agency contracts - Contract entered into between appellant and R-1, a leading bowler of the Indian cricket team, for appellant to act as promotion agents/event managers, etc. for R-1 for three years - Contract containing a "first option" or "right of first refusal" clause in cl. 3l(b) of contract [set out in para 65 herein] - Said clause seeking to impose obligation at the time of expiry of the contract on R-1 not to accept any offer from any third-party promotion agents/event managers without first providing the appellant the opportunity to match the third-party off er - Question arising whether said cl. 3l(b) was a covenant which fell afoul of S. 27 for being in restraint of trade - Supreme Court discussing possible alternative prima facie views since matter had come up before it in interlocutory proceedings, and leaving appellant to pursue its remedy in arbitration for breach of contract as provided for by cl. 32(g) of the contract - All contentions expressly left open - Supreme Court, however refusing to grant interim relief of restraining R-1 from contracting with third parties B. Contract Act, 1872 - S. 27 - Post-contractual covenants or restrictions - When permissible - Held, while construing such covenant or restriction neither test of reasonableness nor principle of restraint being partial is applicable, unless the case falls within the express exception engrafted in S. 27 Dismissing the appeals, the Supreme Court Held: The legal position with regard to post-contractual covenants or restrictions has been consistent, unchanging and completely settled in our country. The legal position clearly crystallised in our country is that while construing the provisions of Section 27 of the Contract Act, neither the test of reasonableness nor the principle of restraint being partial is applicable, unless it falls within the express exception engrafted in Section 27. Even if there were a case for reconsideration of the 132 years old interpretation laid down in Madhup Chunder case, (1874) 14 Beng LR 76, though none is made out by the appellant, such an exercise ought not to be undertaken in the present interlocutory proceedings. (Paras 54 and 44) Under Section 27 of the Contract Act: (a) a restrictive covenant extending beyond the term of the contract is void and not enforceable, (b) the doctrine of restraint of trade does not apply during the continuance of the contract for t From the Final Judgment and Order dated 19-12-2003 of the Bombay High Court in Appeals Nos. 1109 and 1110 of 2003 in Arbitration Petition No. 514 of2003: AIR 2004 Born 362 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Gurumukh Das Saluja, (2004) 3 SCC 155, cited The agreement in the present case has been perused in detail. The terms of the contract were expressly limited to 3 years from 30-10-2000 to 29-10-2003, unless extended by mutual agreement, and all obligations and services under the c contract were to be performed during the term. Clause 31(b) was also to operate only during the term of the contract. This Respondent 1 has scrupulously complied with. So long as clause 31(b) is read as being operative during the term of the agreement i.e. during the period from 29-7-2003 till 29-10-2003, it may be valid and enforceable. On the pleadings contained in the arbitration petition, there can be no escape from the conclusion that what the appellant sought to d enforce, that is clause 3l(b) of the agreement, was a negative covenant which, according to the appellant, survived the expiry of the agreement. This, the High Court has rightly held is impermissible as such a clause which is sought to be enforced after the term of the contract is prima facie void under Section 27 of the Contract Act. (Paras 54, 60 and 61) Clause 31(b) contains a restrictive covenant in restraint of trade as it clearly restricts Respondent 1 from his future liberty to deal with the persons he chooses e for his endorsements, promotions, advertising or other affiliation. If the negative covenant or obligation under clause 3l(b) is sought to be enforced beyond the term of the contract, then it constitutes an unlawful restriction on Respondent l 's freedom to enter into fiduciary relationships with persons of his choice, and a compulsion on him to forcibly enter into a fresh contract with the appellant even though he has fully performed the previous contract, and is, therefore, a restraint f of trade which is void under Section 27 of the Contract Act. (Paras 68 and 62) Again, clause 31(b) of the agreement [set out in para 65 herein] which is being sought to be enforced by the appellants merely provides for an obligation of Respondent 1 to give an opportunity to the appellant to match the offer, if any, received by Respondent 1 from the third party. This clause does not per se restrict or prohibit Respondent 1 to enter into any contract with a third party but at best it provides the appellant with an opportunity to gain from the g advertisements the appellant has made in the process of marketing and creating the image of Respondent 1, which was gradually built up by the appellant. This clause does not restrict the right of Respondent 1 to accept any offer for endorsement, promotion, advertising or other affiliation either on his own or through any party in the event of failure of the appellant to match the offer of the third party from whom Respondent 1 would receive any offer; Respondent 1 h would be free to contract with such third party. Desai that the provision such as the right of first refusal is merely regulatory and not in restraint of trade. Facts 4. The appellant is a company incorporated under the Companies Act, 1956 and carries on business, inter alia, of event management, model and celebrity endorsement and management, charity events/social marketing, all entertainment related activities, sports management and marketing, internet marketing, broadband publicity and radio marketing. 5. Respondent 1 Zaheer Khan is an Indian citizen and a cricketer of international repute. He had entered into an agreement with the appellant. Respondent 2 is a company incorporated under the Companies Act, 1956. 6. The appellant entered into the said agreement with Respondent 1 on 1-11-2000 for a period of 3 years commencing on 30-10-2000 and expiring on 29-10-2003. By a letter of intent dated 29-7-2003, the appellant forwarded to Respondent 1 the draft terms for extension of the said agreement for a further period of 5 years. Respondent 1 informed the representative of the appellant from time to time that he does not intend to appoint any agent for managing his different media affairs. Respondent 1 informed the appellant on 10-9-2003 that he was not desirous of renewing and/or extending the terms of the said agreement and the same would, therefore, terminate as of 29-10- 2003. He further stated that the said letter provided for notice of non-renewal. By the said letter, he informed the appellant of having received the letter of intent and informed the appellant that he was not desirous of signing the same. By the said letter, he confirmed that the 3 agreements stated in the said letter were subsisting. Respondent 1 was further informed that as per the terms of the said agreement, prior to the execution of the first negotiation period provided in clause 3l(a), he could not accept any offer for endorsements, promotions, advertising or other affiliation with regard to any product or services and that prior to accepting any off er, he was under an obligation to provide the appellant in writing all the terms and conditions of such third party and offer the appellant the right to match such third-party offer. Respondent 1, by his letter dated 18-11-2003, alleged that he had no obligation under the said agreement after 29-10-2003, save and except honouring the subsisting agreement entered into by Respondent 1 with third parties as specified in his letter dated 10-9-2003 and the agreement entered c into with Adidas Limited which was negotiated prior to the expiry of the said agreement. In the said letter for the first time, after the said agreement had expired by efflux of time, Respondent 1 alleged that the said agreement was allegedly one-sided and an unfair arrangement. It is pertinent to note that during the entire period of the said agreement, Respondent 1 had not alleged to the appellant that the terms of the said agreement were either one-sided or d unfair. The appellant states that the same was clearly an afterthought. 8. The appellant, for the first time, became aware on 1-12-2003 from some sources and from the website of Respondent 2 that Respondent 1 had entered into an agreement with Respondent 2 for services similar to the services rendered by the appellant under the said agreement. Respondent 1 has not denied the fact that he negotiated with third parties, including e Respondent 2 prior to expiry of the agreement without discharging his obligation to intimate the appellant of such offer. 9. On 4-12-2003, the appellant filed Arbitration Petition No. 514 of 2003 in the High Court under Section 9 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 praying, inter alia, for an interim order that pending the commencement of and during the arbitration proceedings and the making of f the award therein and the implementation thereof, Respondent 1 be restrained by an interim order and injunctio n from entering into any agreement/ arrangement or acting upon or continuing to act upon any agreement/contract with Respondent 2 or any third party without first performing and complying with Respondent 1 's obligations under and in terms of clause 31 ( b) of the agreement. 10. The learned Single Judge of the High Court granted ad interim relief g in terms of prayer clause (a) of the petition. Respondents 1 and 2 preferred separate appeals against the order of the learned Single Judge praying, inter alia, for a stay therein. 11. Aggrieved by the above order, two special leave petitions were filed by the appellant in this Court. This Court stayed the impugned ordert t until further orders. On 27-8-2004, leave was granted. 13. We heard Mr Ashok H. Desai, learned Senior Counsel, appearing for the appellant and Mr Chanderuday Singh, learned Senior Counsel, appearing for Respondent 1 and Mr K.N. Bhat, learned Senior Counsel, appearing for Respondent 2. 14. Mr Ashok H. Desai, learned Senior C ounsel, appearing for the appellant submitted that the High Court has failed to appreciate the true legal meaning and effect of Section 27 of the Contract Act, 1872. He submitted that an agreement of "first option" or the "right of first refusal" of the kind contained in the promotion agreement dated 1-11-2000 entered between the appellant and Respondent 1 can never be said to be an agreement in restraint of trade. Explaining further, he said that the contract of "first refusal" on the ground of option in favour of the appellant is not an independent agreement to promote trade and not an agreement in restraint of trade. He would submit that the High Court was not justified in rejecting the contention of the appellant that the obligation of Respondent 1 in clause 31 (b) of the agreement survives the term of the said agreement. It was also submitted that the High Court is not correct and justified in coming to the conclusion that the agreement is a contract of service. Likewise, the High Court was not justified in coming to the conclusion that the covenant contained in clause 31 (b) of the said agreement was applicable only during the period of contract and not thereafter. The High Court was also not justified in rejecting the appellant's contention that the derogation contained in clause 3l(b) of the agreement is no t in restraint of trade but effectively in furtherance of trade and, therefore, not void under Section 27 of the Contract Act. According to Mr Desai, the covenant in clause 3l(b) of the agreement was an obligation which was to operate after the close of business hours on 29-10-2003. There is also no contention on behalf of Respondent 1 that the agreement was unconscionable or excessively harsh or unreasonable or one-sided. It was submitted that the covenant contained in clause 31 (b) did not restrict Respondent 1 fro m accepting any offer for his endorsements, promotions, advertisements or other services on his own and thus did not restrict Respondent 1 's liberty to carry on his affairs in the manner he liked. The finding and the conclusion of the High Court that the covenant contained in clause 31 (b) of the agreement curtailed Respondent 1 to accept any offer for his endorsement, promotion, etc. by dealing with any person on his own. According to Mr Desai, the facts in this case clearly disclose the a nature of the promotion agreement entered into between the parties and the benefit obtained by Respondent 1 as well as the appellant. The promotion agreement dated 1-11-2000 is a class of contracts, common in the industry, that may be termed as "celebrity contracts". While arguing the case, Mr Desai highlighted certain provisions of the agreement which are as follows: b (i) Under the agreement, the appellant was appointed as the sole and exclusive agent to manage and market the affairs of the respondent. (ii) In consideration for this appointment, Respondent 1 was guaranteed a minimum amount of Rs 55 lakhs per year. In reality, he was able to obtain Rs 1 crore per year. (iii) Such a celebrity contract involves considerable risk to the agent c (in this case, the appellant) who has to guarantee a large amount and to invest considerable amounts of money at a substantial risk in creating and promoting a particular person as a brand. The reciprocal promise obtained from the opposite party (in this case, Respondent 1) is in the form of a right of first refusal. (iv) The agreement provided for an initial term of three years (from d 30-10-2000 to 29-10-2003) and extension thereof for such further period as may be mutually agreed. (v) The extension was contemplated, inter alia, pursuant to the terms of clause 31 of the agreement pursuant to which Respondent 1 was to negotiate on an exclusive basis with the appellant for a prescribed period. (vi) Thereafter, clause 3 l(b) contained a right of first refusal clause e pursuant to which the appellant was to be given an opportunity to match any third-party offer made to Respondent 1 before Respondent 1 was permitted to enter into the third-party agreement. If the appellant failed to match the third-party offer, Respondent 1 was free to enter into a contract with the third party. If the appellant matched the offer, Respondent 1 suffered no detriment. In either case, it cannot be said that Respondent 1 f was restrained in any manner and more importantly, the right of first refusal clause has no detrimental impact on Respondent 1 Zaheer Khan whatsoever. It is submitted that such right of first refusal provision is customary in agreements of this nature. (vii) The agreement contains an arbitration clause to refer disputes to arbitration. g (viii) It is the undisputed position that both parties performed their respective obligations under the agreement and that Respondent 1 therefore benefited financially for the 3 years that the agreement was in force.
